Was ever Marriage ſo croſt, they'r all gone, and have left me nothing to keep me Company, but a guilty Conſcience; Oh the horror of it ſtrikes me dead; Murder is the ſin Committed, and I the only Actor! Oh Vanlore, could I recall thy Soul, I willingly would give my Daughter to you to ſatisfie the injuries I did you, but 'tis in vain, the Bloody deed is done, I ſhall grow mad, my Son and Daughter and my Wits are loſt, loſt paſt Redemption,
sp.l: Howe're I'le ſpin my Life out, though my Grief
Burden my Soul till it is paſt Relief.

div.head: SCENE a Plane.
div.stage: Enter Oroandes Reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p:
Meet me at Nine behind the Hermits Rock. I have not miſt in either Circumſtance, unleſs my haſt Anticipated Time — Looks on his Watch.
It yet is not full Nine.
Enter Antellus.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oroandes you are now a Loyal Subject.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: All my Ambitions ne're flew higher, Sir, then in that Region of your thoughts to thrive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There it was grown to full Maturity: But I muſt like wanton Nero either Ruin all the Glorious Structure of thy hopes, or live Impris'ned in thy Loyalty: thy Life (till now my ſtrongeſt fortreſs) is become the fatal Engine of my Ruin.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Heav'n! what have I done to merit this?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nothing but bin too Vertuous, and by that center'd affections which I muſt remove, or ſhake thee into Chaos.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: This Language blaſts me, ſure I have no ſin pond'rous enough to buoy your Veng'ance up. Did I but think one Viper Lodg'd in my remoteſt part, I'de tear each Fibre of my heart, to find the Monſter out, and in my blood Imbalm'd throw it as far as Lifes ſhort ſpan can reach. But Heav'n my witneſs is no flame of Zeal, but has bin your's i'th' ſecond Magnitude; my Vows of Kin to thoſe I pay'd the Gods, my Prayers but Love and Duty fir'd into a holy Calenture.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thy Vertue fathoms not my debt of Guilt; ſuch a prevention of my Anger, would only change the active paſſion for ſorrow as inſupportable: thoſe Characters which muſt uphold the ſables of my Soul, are in dark Hieroglyphicks hid, through which thy ſtrength of Judgment cannot pierce.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: You ſpeak in miſty wonders Sir, ſuch as lead my apprehenſion into wild Meanders.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This will unriddle all our doubts, — draw. King draws.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Againſt my Soveraign! an Act ſo wicked would retort the guilty ſteel into my breaſt: fear never yet Marbled a Cowards heart more then Obedience mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Will you deny when I Command?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Pardon me Royal Sir, I would beſtride a Cloud with Lightning Charg'd in's full Carreer, affront a Thunderbolt, leap into the Clefts of Earthquakes, or attempt to prop the Ruines of a falling Rock,
sp.l: Yet count all this my happineſs, ſo I
Met Death in the white Robes of Loyalty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Are my attempts priz'd at ſo weak a rate? wears not my
Sword a danger on its poynt as well as thine? — Draw — or I ſhall conclude 'tis fear, not Loyalty, that Charms thy hand, which ſpeaks thy Soul a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: This ſtirs my blood, were you a private man that only had his better Genius to defend him, and though Ally'd to me by all the tyes of Nature, and of Friendſhip, yet being thus far urg'd, our Swords long ſince had ſhown whoſe Stars had brighteſt Influence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I have unfetter'd all thoſe legal bonds. Draw — for thy denying now but ſlights my power.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Then ſince there's no Evaſion, — Oroandes draws.
Witneſs ye Gods my Innocence is wrong'd.
But Gracious Sir, — Oroandes kneels.
sp.p: Before I fall, or ſtand leſs fortunate, to ſee you overthrew, Oh let me know what Fate, what Cruel Fate has Rob'd me of the Treaſure of your Love.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And muſt ſuch goodneſs die? Know noble Youth, I am ſo far from calling it deſert in thee, that hath unſheath'd my Sword, that in this midnight ſtorm of fancy I can ſhed ſome drops of Pitty too. I come not raſhly to attempt thy life, but long have ſtruggled with my hot deſires, ſtood fiery Tryals of temptations. I am diſeas'd, and know no way to health but through a deluge of thy blood, — there is a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Dear Sir reveal it, that e're I fall, my penitential tears may cleanſe my Soul from ſuch a Leprous Crime.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Alas brave Youth, thy thought's white as the Robes of Angels are, I know thy Love to fair Amaſia inſeperable, as goodneſs from a Deity, yet I muſt deprive thee of this Darling of thy Soul.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: With pardon Royal Sir, I cannot think the Cyprian Princeſs is ſo ſoon forgot, with whom Amaſia Sir compar'd is nothing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Darſt thou affect her, yet diſpraiſe a Beauty that in its Orb contracts Divinity? This Prophanation what had elſe bin ſin will render Meritorious, — Guard thy Life.

div.stage: They fight, the King is wounded.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: What have I done?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Buſineſs that we met for, now we are friends again, friends until Death. The King ſtaggers and falls.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Oh do not faint, call up your ſpirits Sir, there's hopes of Life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My Vital Powers fail, my Eyes are bowing to Eternal night.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: And I grow wild with Horror, — milder then a Flame provok'd by angry Winds; what ſhall I do, or whither ſhall I flie, to leave behind me this purſuing Guilt? A noiſe within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh, Oh, — be gone, be gone my Oroandes, ſome Company draws near. Maiſt thou live long and happily in the Embraces of her whom I unjuſtly ſtrove to have: my dying wiſhes wait upon your joys.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.l: Angels attend your lateſt hour, I go
From hence to meet my Everlaſting woe. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Heroina, Vanlore, Shepherds, and Shepherdeſſes.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: I thought I heard th' unruly noiſe of Swords,
And Claſhing Murmurs of unfriendly words,
Beſides the Eccho of a hollow Groan.

sp.speaker: Van
sp.l: I heard the diſmal noiſe, and fear th' event,
Theſe wild Bandetties live by ſpoiles alone,
Run on in ſin, and fear no puniſhment.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh, Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: — What noiſe is that?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: — Some newly Slain
By theſe untam'd Bandetties of the Plaine.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.l: And here lies one breathing his lateſt breath,
His face is cold, and all appears like Death;
Let's Beare him off
Within for his Recovery all means I'le try,
For ſomething prompts me, that he muſt not die.

div.stage: They take him up, and Exeunt. Enter Theocrine and the Shepherd, the Shepherd brings back Vanlore.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: My deareſt Theocrine, in all, you prove
Your Honour great, as is your Real Love.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My Vanlore, ſure I may believe my eyes,
Or doth the ſuddain Joy my ſenſe ſurprize;
The Cruel pleaſures ſteal ſo ſweetly on,
Makes me miſtruſt the Bliſs I run upon.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Your Bliſs is Real, and my Joy's Compleat,
Heav'n could not give a happineſs more great.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Through doubts and fears I have attain'd my will,
But 'twas unkind to let me Languiſh ſtill.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: That only caſt a Cloud on the deſign,
That with more eaſe you might to Love incline.
And I to live alone retir'd with pain,
Expecting ſtill this happineſs to gain;
Which thus poſſeſt, more perfect Bliſs I find,
Then in the various pleaſures of the mind.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Love like the wind oft ſhifts and ſeems to ceaſe,
As if each minute lull'd it into peace;
Sweetly it breaths upon the flowry Plaine,
And yet a moment pulls it back again.
From Calms to Storms th' unruly Guſt doth riſe,
And ſcatters all the Clouds about the Skies;
So we neglectful, now our Bliſs is near,
By ſtaying, threaten dangers we ſhould fear:
My Lovers Anger, and my Fathers Age,
With Thunder will purſue us in his Rage.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Thou art the Loadſtone, and my Soul ſhall be
Directed only by thy Charms and thee.
'Mongſt harmleſs Sheep, and ſolitary Bowers,
We'l waſt the tedious Time in pleaſant Hours▪
There Love and Pleaſure we'l at once poſſeſs;
Who wades through Croſſes meets true Happineſs. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Court.
div.stage: Enter Zannazarro, Glorianda, and Amaſia.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: How ſad a change is this! This morning was appointed for more joyful Enterviews.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: When laſt nights ſlumber rob'd our wakeful hopes of the delicious births of fancy, 'twas with fairer promiſes: Amaſia, I fain would comfort thee, but my own griefs make me a ſtranger to that balmy Language.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p:
Dear Siſter, thy Paſſions are too violent; the Meſſengers are not yet all return'd, nor have we ſeen Arratus.
Enter Arratus.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: And here he comes.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: My Lord, you either come to ſhare in Grief with us, or eaſe ours by ſome bleſt diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: My Lord, my Son, my Daughter, and my —

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Peace, no more, mix not theirs with a Sov'raigns loſs, whoſe leaſt drop of Blood is worth a Thouſand Lives, ſpeak thy intelligence.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: My Largeſt lies within the City walls, and there he has not yet bin heard of; is none with him?

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p:
Yes, Oroandes,
Enter a Meſſenger. here comes our laſt hopes, ſpeak thy ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.p: Not good my Lord, we've traveſt all the Fields that Circles lofty Erix, and yet ſee no beam of bleſt Intelligence; all we found worthy to fix an Obſervation on, was a place beneath the Hermits Rock all ſtain'd with ſtore of Blood, and near the foot this token of our Grief. Gives a bloody Handkercher which was the Kings.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Oh my Prophetick fears!

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: Our ſorrows are confirm'd!

sp.speaker: Glor.
sp.p: They are in Bloody Characters!

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: I'le go and ſecure the Cittadel, and cry Treaſon.

div.stage: Exit. Arratus.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Sorrow out-grows all my Reſolves, this is an Act ſo full of Horror 'tis terrible to name it; but if the Force of Syracuſe can ſcourge the Traytors,
sp.l: — We'l have
Their Heads to build a Temple o're his Grave.

div.head: SCENE the Plaines.
div.stage: Enter the King lead by two Shepherds and Heroina.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I'VE now got ſtrength enough to render to you the fair preſerver of my Life; my Spirits ſtir, as if they would ſhake off the ſluggiſh weight of weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: How much in ev'ry twinkling of the eye doth he reſemble my Heroick Love. Aſide.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You'r ſad ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I have a Cauſe, and ſuch a one, that did you know, your Goodneſs would Commiſerate my wretched Fortune.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Reveal it Lady, I perhaps may be inabled then to diſſipate your Griefs.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p:
I was reſolv'd to weep away my Time in private ſorrow; but diſcovery cannot aggravate my woe; beſides I may venture to
lodge a ſecret, where I have found ſuch temperate vertues. I'le only with this Queſtion Uſher in my own diſcovery; is Sicily your place of Birth, or not?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It is, and Breeding both.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I will not ask what were the Parentage, where I find Vertues plant Nobility, yet would be loath to a Plebeian breaſt to truſt what I muſt now divulge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You may be confident I am a Gentleman, as well by Birth as Education, Lady.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I do preſume it Sir, and therefore wiſh of all I now remain amongſt to be known unto you alone. You never had Relation to the Court?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There was my Breeding Lady.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Near the Perſon of the King?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: One of his Bed-Chamber, and 'tis no boaſt to ſay, as well belov'd by him as any, there being in th' opinion of the Court, a near Reſemblance of our looks.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Then ſure my name is not a ſtranger to you, have you not heard Sir of the Cyprian Princeſs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The Beautious Heroina.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: The wretched Heroina, ſuch I'm ſure is my condition in my preſent State.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Pardon the Child of Ignorance, my wild, and unbecoming Rudeneſs. Kneels.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Riſe Sir, we are Companions yet; and hope we ſhall be till your Royal Maſter poſſeſs what was long ſince intended his. By what Diſaſter, I was caſt upon this dreadful Precipice of Danger, as we are walking I'le Relate. Enter two Bandetties.

sp.speaker: I Ban.
sp.p: A prize, a prize, a noble prize, ſeize you upon that pretty Shepherdeſs, while I diſpatch the Guardian. Draws.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'Tis not ſo quickly done, and though as yet unable to defend, hither I'le fly for Reſcue.
Snatches the Bandetties Sword, who is going to ſeize Heroina. Now I'm prepar'd to ſcourge your ſawcy Inſolence.

div.stage: Fights with the firſt Bandetty and wounds him, the ſecond leaves Heroina, and offers to ſeize the King; Enter Vanlore and Theocrine, Vanlore Draws, and drives the ſecond Bandetty off; the firſt that was wounded by the King ſtayes.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: This was a timely Reſcue, and has by the fair Redemption of my Honour bound me to give you thanks.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I merit none; my Duty urg'd me to preſerve that Life which they ſtrove thus to Raviſh. The brighteſt Stars that Rul'd my Fate, did light me to this bleſt Employment; but had all ſet, e're their Influence had attain'd its end, had not this Gentlemans aſſiſtance lent new Vigor to their fading Beams.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs a debt of thanks to him, which if Irregular Humanity prove no Rebel to my ſafety, ſhall be ſuddainly diſcharg'd: Let this Villain attend us to the Court, there you'l find a Prince to be intreated, when your Advocate bears Heroina's name. I can forgive, and ſo I hope can you, although his Crimes merit a laſting puniſhment.

sp.speaker: 1 Ban.
sp.p: Pardon me beſt of Women, and impute Kneels. my Rudeneſs to my Ignorance. If any Service can Extenuate Crimes of ſuch Monſtrous Growth, my Blood ſhall pay the forfeit of my diſobedience.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: Your hopes of ſafety prompts me to believe you: Come Sir, you and that Gentleman ſhall attend me to the Court.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: We are your Vaſſals Madam, proud to have ſuch a Command to Uſher our deſires.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: And you Sir.
sp.l: There I'le compleat that cure ſo well begun,
And raiſe your fading hopes for what you've done.

div.head: SCENE a Tavern. A Table, Pen Ink and Paper in it.
div.stage: Enter Led by the Noſe, Sir Jaſper Sympleton by Drayner, and Sir Symon Credulous by Slywit, diſguis'd.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Come, come along Sir, is't not enough to kill an honourable Gentleman, but you muſt Lampoon him when you've done, and wound his fame in Verſe.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p:
Dam-me if ever I writ a Verſe in my Life, or any thing like it, alas I have no more wit then a Gooſe, and writing's as diſagreeable
to my Nature, as Hanging: I muſt confeſs I have often had an Itching mind to Poetry, but could never obtain it.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And what makes your name Sir, crowded on the Title Page of ſeveral Plays in ſplendid Characters, as if that Oſtentation did proclaim thee a man of wit and merit?

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I ſee you are Ignorant of the Engliſh Cuſtomes; their men of Wit and Sence inclin'd to Poetry, have ſuch a little ſhare in the Worlds Treaſure, their works and them alike go both a begging, and ſcarce a morning but we Eaſie-men (who rather then our lives would be accounted the Zanies of the Age) are troubled with their Viſits, where for a Guinny we purchaſe the Labour of three Months, and then by our Authority, with the Acting Females (who do at upon us Gallants of the Times) the Play in our name's Acted, and by Conſequence, 'cauſe all the World ſhould be acquainted with our Folly (which we think Wit) ſome Greedy Bookſeller pays dear for the Copy, and by his means 'tis Uſher'd into th' World; thoſe Dedications writ by us (ſmall Criticks) never are honour'd by a Noble Patroneſs, tending to down right rayling at the Age, or finding fault perhaps with the beſt Poets.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: This makes you Guilty of the laſt Lampoon, in which you have not only abus'd him who never was a Poet, but all the Poets of the Age; and therefore if you give us not (in the behalf of our dead Friend) ſufficient ſatisfaction, you die immediately.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: This 'tis to pretend to Poetry in a ſtrange Country: I Gad in London, a man of Nonſence is as ſafe (amongſt the Crue of Criticks) as in a Hollands Leaguer, for they are more given to the Spirit of Contradiction, then that of Fighting. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Come Sir, diſpatch, we are in haſt.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: So am I to be gone. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Swear Sir.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Swear what?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Either you did, or did not write the Verſes.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I vow to Gad, and all that, I am Innocent.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: That's but a weak Oath, and ſhows too muſt of Cowardize to gain belief, ſwear me a full mouth'd Oath like a true Engliſhman.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Then on the Vertue of a Gentleman, and Honour of Sir Symon Credulous, I am not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Honour and Vertue are two mighty ſtrangers to an Ignoble breaſt; I cannot in the leaſt Imagine they are lodg'd in your's. Come Gentlemen, here's Pen Ink and Paper, write ev'ry Letter that we ſhall command you, or die in diſobeying.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Was ever poor Pretended led by the Noſe before? Honour begone, to ſave my Life I'le do it; we are ready Sir.

div.stage: Sir Jaſper and Sir Symon go to the Table, and prepare to write.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Write this then, — I am a Coward.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: All the World knows that already, it needs no publication.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Write I Command you.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: I am a Coward. — Write.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: An Arrand ſtinking Coward.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: An Arrand ſtinking Coward. — Write.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: A Poetical Thief.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: Not I by Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Write I ſay.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: A — Write.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And a damm'd Son of a Whore, if ever I writ theſe Verſes.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: And a — Write.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: All this I Gad is true Gentlemen, have you done?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Not yet Sir, one word more, and I do here promiſe to receive into my Arms, the Lady yeſterday Married, to have and to hold, for better for worſe, and ſo forth, with a promiſe to make her a Jointure of Three Hundred a Year; to keep (and never to part with) her, as being a Match only fit for me — Jaſper Sympleton.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.l: Withal my heart. Jaſper writes.
Now Sir Symon I think I am even with you. Aſide.
Here Sir I deliver this to you as my Act and Deed.

div.stage: Gives Drayner the Paper.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: So this is well. And now Gentlemen, 'cauſe you ſhall be eas'd of all your fears and miſeries, all diſputations 'twixt you two muſt ceaſe; the Lady, the Beautious Lady Theocrine by Nuptial tye is yours, and as your Wife receive her.

div.stage: Enter Julia.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: Withal my heart, now you have plaid the part of honeſt men, welcome into my Arms.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Pray Heav'n you find us ſo, do you know me Sir?

div.stage: Diſcovers himſelf.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: What Drayner, Servant to my Rival Sir Symon Credulous, nay then I fear the worſt.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I am the honeſt man you talk of Sir, and 'cauſe you ſhall not dwell in Ignorance too long, behold whom you have Married.

div.stage: Diſcovers Julia.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: Cheated, Gul'd, abus'd by Heav'n; have I Married this Chamber-maid?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: This Chamber-woman you have Sir, I was a Maid until you made me otherwiſe; and afterwards you would perſwade me to have bin as falſe as Dunkirk, and in one hour have received Engliſh, Dutch, French, and abus'd them all; but you ſee the Fates decreed it otherwiſe, I am now your Wife.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: The Devil ſhall be mine as ſoon; go home to your old Office, keep the Door, and let in ev'ry paultry Knight or Squire, that gives a Guinny and a Kiſs for Entrance, who being ſlighted by your Peeviſh Lady, falls foul on you, as being loath to loſe th' Imagination of Enjoyment, though with her meaneſt Servants.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Good Bully Sympleton, how like an Aſs you look now, I muſt confeſs you have ſuch a ſmart way of Courtſhip, ſuch taking Charms, ſuch ſweet Devices, no Woman can hold out. Wiſh you much Joy Sir. Gad Drayner let's ſerenade him with the ſecond part to the ſame Tune.
sp.l: I had a Miſs, a Dainty, Dainty Miſs,
Who could at once, Diſſemble, Cog, and Kiſs;
This Miſs I Gad grew weary of the Life,
Jilted Sir Jaſper, and became a Wife.
sp.p: How do you like it Bully, Ha?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Come, come Sir, be patient, you are now a Knight Alamode, a Courtier of the Faſhion, for ſcarce one of them but Marry ſome Debauch'd Lady or other, and count it happineſs if but three Nations have enjoy'd her; and this Paſty is of your own Cutting up, and no doubt will prove a Vertuous Wife.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: A Vertuous Devil ſhe may: Pox of the Sex in general, and in particular thee: farewel Wife, farewel Bully; mayſt thou Love on, till thou Reelſt like a Drunken Dutchman, and in that Humour Commit Adultery with ſome Gotiſh Citizen, till the hot Peſtilence of Pleaſure ſink thee into another World.

div.stage: Offers to go, but is hindred by Drayner.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Stay Sir, ſtay, I have your hand here to confirm a Contract, which I give up to Julia, and here I vow by all thoſe Plagues you heap'd upon her head, to kill you inſtantly, unleſs you take her to your Arms.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: Why this to your friend Drayner? Pox you' • a man of Wit, and Merit, and I know have more diſcretion, then to Bubble your Obliging Friend and Servant.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd nothing ſhall ſtop my fury; take her, or —

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: Pox on ye, come, had I Courage enough to die, I would be hang'd before I'de have a Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: A Chamber-maid, Ha, Ha, Ha; give me thy hand Sympleton, give you much joy, a Chamber-maid, Ha.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: Well, well Sir, let nothing trouble you, my Chamber-maid may be a Lady as ſoon as your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Give you much joy, I ſay no more Bully, but now I hope I may Court my Miſtreſs without the trouble of Poetiſing, Drinking, or Whoring, Ha, Bully Sympleton.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: You may Sir, but ſhe's Married.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: The Devil ſhe is, to whom?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: A Shepherd Sir, one poor but honeſt, and ſuch a one as Nature only made equal in Graces to compare with her, won by her prayers and tears; I ſtole her hence, and gave her to a faithful Shepherd, who was her Conduct to him.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: S'death am I gold by Shepherds? the baſe Slaves ſhall die: who was the Principal?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p:
One though unfortunate, may boaſt himſelf a Souldier
and a Gentleman, one whom ſhe thought was Dead, the worthy Vinbore.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: A very honeſt fellow I Gad, and one I love extreamly, though I never ſaw him; he ſhall enjoy her, my bleſſing wait upon him, that is, continual Love, and want of Women Kind, light on him.

div.stage: Enter a Conſtable▪ and Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: There, there are the Murderers, ſeize on 'em all; if they refuſe, knock'em down, we have the Law on our ſides.

div.stage: They offer to ſeize 'em.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Draw Gentlemen, they b •• e the ſight of a Sword.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Not I by Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: Not I by Jove; what Draw againſt a Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: What Brother Conſtable, are you here?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Keep off Sir, how came you to be my Brother?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: When you were hot upon the ſearch for my Maſter, this Gentlemans Murderer, I to ſecure his Perſon which might caſually fall into your hands, and to create a Jeſt, diſguis'd my ſelf into the ſhape of an Officer, and coming into your Company, I carried you to the Tavern, where both the Murderer and Murther'd ſtood like Images, and to maintain the Jeſt, I appear'd as fearful as your Worſhip, giving the firſt ſtart at what I knew ſo well, Sir Symon Credulous in Armor. Diſcovers himſelf.

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: What Sly, my ſubtle ſerving-man?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: The ſame Sir, born to bring you out of theſe dangerous troubles.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Was there no Ghoſt in the Tavern then?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: None I aſſure you, unleſs theſe Gentlemen are Devils.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Oh diſhonour to our Office, and ſtain to this ſtaff of Dignity, ſeize upon 'em all, I'le teach you to abuſe Authority, you are as wicked as Players, who make no more of a Conſtable, then of a Cobler.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: The Cauſe you ſeize us for's ſo means we ſcorn to ſtand againſt it, — here we all yield our ſelves, do what you can, or dare. All deliver their Swords.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Nay now you are Civil Gentlemen, and wer't not that I have another Warrant, which is too great to diſobey, I'de give you all your Liberties; the King is loſt, and 'tis to be ſuppos'd Murther'd,
upon which I have Order to ſecure ev'ry ſuſpitious Perſon▪

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: How the King loſt?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And Murder'd!

sp.speaker: Jaſ.
sp.p: Oh Horror!

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: Nay now we may be hang'd indeed, but ſure the King had more wit then to die of his own accord, 'tis mear Treaſon by Jove.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: It can't be leſ • , therefore Gentlemen till news comes of our Soveraign, this Tavern ſhall be your Goal, to no worſe place I'le carry you.

sp.speaker: Sym.
sp.p: I Gad thou art the merrieſt Conſtable in Europe; come along Brother Traytors, Madam Sympleton you are a Conſpirator too, come along Boys:
sp.l: When ſparkiſh Bacchanalians Traytors • urn,
We'l ſwim through Fire, and in Canary burn.

div.stage:
Exeunt. Mane •
Sly and Drayner.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.l: So now we are Reveng'd, and Profits grow
More great, then e're this Fop • has to b • ſtow,
When Profit and Revenge together meet;
Each hour ſucceſſes Crown'd fall at our feet:
How bright each Motion to that Bliſs doth prove!
Revenge once Compaſs'd, taſts more ſweet then Love. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE the Court.
div.stage: Enter the King and Vanlore, leading Heroina, attended by Theocrine Shepherds, and Shepherdeſſes, at one door; at the other, Zannazarro, Glorianda, and Amaſia, all in Mourning, attended by the Kings Guard, Zannazarro kneels, and having kiſs'd Heroina's hand, Roſes.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: The beſt of welcomes this ſad place affords wait on your Grace's Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, but muſt firſt Employ your ſervice in declaring, what theſe ſilent Emblems of a ſorrow means?

sp.speaker: Zan.
Glo.
sp.p: Help, help the Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: Madam, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Oh, Oh, Oh.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: Bear her forth, and give her more Air.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p:
Hold, I am better here; if any thing revive my Spirits, 'twill be this that puts me in mind of my deceaſed Lord. Why ſtand you thus amaz'd?
Enter Oroandes, Zannazarro, and the reſt ſeem amazed.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Pardon us Madam; had the united duſt of ſome dead friend, whoſe memories ne're forgot, viſited Earth in his own ſhape again, our wonder could not have arriv'd unto a higher Pitch. Let me Embrace thee friend.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Stand off, yet farther off, — you know not what you touch; you ſafer far may grapple with a flame; or in his midnight walks, affront a friend arm'd with full Vials of deſtructive wrath: the Graves Inhabitants, when folded in Corruption, are not more defil'd then I.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: What tends this Language to?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Deſtruction, Zannazarro.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: How haſt thou loſt thy Temper Oroandes, prithee look on me friend, am I grown a ſtranger to thy knowledg?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Leave me Amaſia, thou art of kin unto thoſe hollow'd Angels that did once attend my Actions, and muſt now with them a ſtranger to thy Oroandes grow.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: You are to me a ſtranger Sir, yet in your looks ſomething I read, that may concern your abſent Prince.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: I do, and would Relate it, but that it hath a ſound ſo full of horror, I tremble to Relate it; yet I muſt, no other way can lead my Soul out of this wilderneſs of fleſh; he's Murther'd.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: By whom?

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: By me, do ve ſtart? 'twas I, 'twas I, that when your blooming hope chear'd with the Sun of Majeſty, were grown big with expected favours, did Eclipſe the Glorious Light in a Black Cloud of Death; I cut the heart-ſtrings of the Land, and fed the Groaning Land with Blood, whoſe Purple had bin by an Ancient Stock of Anceſtors dy'd into Royalty.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Ingrateful Slave, why are our Swords ſo ſlow to Execute the Villain? Offers to Draw.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.p: Oh hold, believe him not, he Raves.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p: Thou haſt but injur'd me Amaſia, in ſtaying their juſt fury.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p: Oh Brother if this be true, thou haſt undone us all.

sp.speaker: Oro.
sp.p:
True, do not think this any Natural Diſtemper, that ſpreads this Malignant Vapour through my Veins, which nought but the Poiſon of my Guilt Corrupts; yes I have done it Brother, and you are all bound, as you love your Prince, to ſee't Reveng'd with Torments; here's a Note will when I'm dead, direct you where to find him.
Flings Zannazarro a Note.
And now I've done my Buſineſs on the Earth, I'le give the firſt ſtroke to Revenge, and here open a paſſage for your Swords to Enter. Draws his Sword, and offers to kill himſelf; is ſtay'd by the King. What bold hand is that?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
One that here may claim a priviledg.
Diſcovers himſelf, all kneel by Heroina. Riſe thou true Mirror of all Royalty, ne're higher in our favour.

sp.speaker: Zan.
sp.p: Our Gracious Soveraign!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Welcome, Oh welcome Royal Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
You are all my much lov'd Subjects, ſuch in whom never was King more Bleſt; Madam your preſence Crowns our Joys, now I ſtand Exalted in the Zenith of my Fate; who would not paſs a Stormy Night, to be thus Courted by a Glorious Day? You all are ſharers in my heart, but thou my Love
To Heroina. the chief Commandreſs of that Royal Fort.

sp.speaker: Hero.
sp.p: My Joys are now Compleated, and I find a Sea of Pleaſure Crowns my Dangers paſt; what thoſe were, at your leiſure I'le Relate.
sp.l: Now Joy and Thanks alike my Breſt poſſeſs,
Which leads me to a World of Happineſs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hymen ſhall light us to that World of Joy,
Which once poſſeſs'd, ſhall all our Cares deſtroy.

sp.speaker: Arratus.
sp.p: I ſhould chide you, but 'tis no time to wear an angry brow, although the Crime was monſtrous,, to hier two wicked Slaves to Murder Vanlore, who then lay Leaguer at Ardenna, but by Miracle preſerv'd, to ſave mine and Heroina's Life, for which all he deſires, is your free Conſent to Marry Theocrine.

div.stage: Vanlore and Theocrine kneels.

sp.speaker: Arr.
sp.p: My Lord he has it and I Joy to hear his Life was ſav'd to Act 〈◊〉 brave a •• eed, Riſe and receive my Bleſſing, you are a worthy So • .

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: To add a Title to that Honour, I here Create him 〈◊〉 you Oroandes to a Place of greater worth, and nearer to our 〈◊〉 , thy Loyal 〈◊〉 merrits it.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p:
Long live Ante ••••
and Heroina, King and Queen of Scicily.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My Debts are great to all, but muſt remain in full Arrears until my Off'rings pa • 'd to • air Heroina give me liberty:
sp.l: Then lull'd in Peace▪ and by this • rize ſe • down,
Wee'l find new ways paſt Victories to Crown.
The mighty Bliſs about my Soul doth move
In diff'rent forms, like unknown Joys Above,
B'ing Crown'd at once with Loyalty and Love.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: WHAT ſtrange unkindneſs doth amongſt you Reign,
Sure you will ne're leave off this Damming ſtrein;
You Sans remorſe, like Cruel Victors kill;
Both Friend and Foe muſt ſuffer by your will,
And all you do is good, though ne're ſo ill;
Your Native ſweetneſs ſure is from you fled,
And all kind Nature is Extinct and Dead;
Like Miſs Enjoy'd, you lead us to the Door,
Quite Cloy'd, you thruſt us out, and Love no more,
Leave us like her to all Enſuing harms,
And Curſe the ill, becauſe you hate her Charms:
By Inſtigation, or by Precept led,
You that are Wits the Guiddy faction head;
And taught by them, ill Nature and their ſpight,
Y' Explode what they call wrong, though ne're ſo right.
Like Maſſanello's our kind Judges ſit,
Cry down the Play, becauſe they hate the Wit;
Damm me ſayes one, why ſo Satyrick here,
What means the Fop to Ramble from his ſphere,
And Carp at things, the graveſt Poets fear?
Troth 'twas Invention, though he miſt the way,
He writ, and hop'd to pleaſe as well as they,
But he miſto • k, and Jaded his poor Muſe,
And what he though Jocoſe, prov'd mere abuſe.
The Drudging Scribler quakes within, for fear
You ſhould turn Hectors and diſſect him here;
His little frailty ſure you can forgive,
And Impudence you know deſerves to live;
You may be merciful, though you are Foes,
Since to your Rage at once he did Expoſe
All he held dear, to Lead you by the Noſe.
